candidates.title: Did a Pink Volcano Erupt in New Zealand?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A video purportedly showing bright fuschia smoke billowing from a volcano frequently appears on social media, along with a claim that it shows an actual "pink volcano" erupting in New Zealand:
Pink eruption of the volcano in New Zealand
The video does not explain what chemical process might turn smoke or steam this particular shade (although with the proper dyes, it is possible to turn smoke into a veritable rainbow), but it isn't particularly relevant anyway; this video does not depict an actual volcanic eruption.
The "pink volcano" video was created by artist Filip Hodas, and was originally shared to his Facebook page in December 2016. Hodas posted the video to Instagram (with tags such as #3D, #photoshop, #render, and #animation), and provided extra insight into how the video was created in response to a query on Facebook:
pretty much! depends on what I need. In this case I layered few planes with wm maps on top of each other and added a lot of zdepth fog to blend it in.
No records of volcanos emitting bright pink smoke exist, except those created by digital artists.
candidates.description: Video purportedly showing oddly-colored smoke and steam rising from a eruption was digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The provided news caption, "An actual \"pink volcano\" erupting in New Zealand," is directly contradicted by the evidence from Snopes.  Snopes explicitly states that the video depicting a pink volcano eruption in New Zealand is digitally manipulated and false.  There are no records of actual volcanoes emitting bright pink smoke.
result.supporting_points: Source 1 explicitly states that the video of a pink volcano eruption in New Zealand is false and digitally manipulated.  It also notes that no records exist of volcanoes emitting bright pink smoke except for those created digitally.

final_result.explanation: The original news caption claims an actual "pink volcano" erupted in New Zealand. Furthermore, Snopes points out the lack of any documented cases of naturally occurring volcanoes producing bright pink smoke. This external evidence strongly contradicts the news caption.  Since the external verification provides strong evidence against the caption's accuracy and the internal check could not offer an assessment due to missing visual data, the final verdict is that the caption is out of context.  The high confidence score reflects the strong evidence from a reliable external source that directly refutes the caption's central claim.  The absence of supporting visual evidence from the original image further reinforces this conclusion.
